Posted: November 25, 2013
												A good addon to the Company of Heroes franchise. Adds two new playable teams; the British (a hardcore defensive team), and the Panzer Elite (very hit and run with good heavy tanks in endgame). Maps are also added but few in number. Could be a little better balanced but if you fancy a challenge in MP, hit up the British, we like a challenge!

number of helpful: 34 of 37 people (92%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												If you liked CoH, you'll like this. Opposing Fronts is a standalone expansion for Company of Heroes. It adds 2 new armies (The British and the Panzer Elite) for multiplayer/AI matches, two new campaigns for both factions, unique new doctrines and tons of new units with loads of abilities. -Armies/UnitsThe British are a good solid defensive faction. Most of their power comes from emplacements you build.Pros- Command Trucks are used for HQs, meaning you can place them in any of your secured territories, boosting its resource output. Heavy defensive positions like Slit Trenches, MG Positions, AT gun emplacements and Mortar emplacements can be built for a small amount of resources and population. Infantry can be upgraded with many different weapons, increasing their efficency against other infantry, light vehicles or heavy tanks. Their doctrines offer Commando Support which allows you to land a glider with 6 Commandos, a glider with a light tank that is effective against halftracks, infantry and other light tanks, and a HQ glider which allows the production of AT commandos, Mortar Commandos and HMG commandos.Cons- They are purely defensive (unless you use the Commando Doctrine) and do not have much offensive capabilty. Their infantry walks very slowly through enemy or uncaptured territory to gain more defensive against attacks (which is annoying at the start). Their tanks (aside from the Sherman Firefly) all have small guns but heavy armor that can't do♥♥♥♥♥♥against many medium to heavy tanks. -The Panzer Elite are a very mobile faction. Most of their amor is made up of halftracks (which can be pretty powerful) but they can get some good heavy tanks and tank destroyers. Pros- Great faction for quick and powerful attacks. Infantry halftracks let the garrisoned squad shoot out the top with any weapons they have (bazzokas, mgs or snipers). The Marder tank destroyer is extremely good with an ability to "lock-down" making it immoblie but a faster rate of fire that does more damage. Almost all of their infantry can repair stuff. Cons- As said before, their armor are halftracks. -Overall Score: 8.5/10 A good game but better as an expansion to CoH 1.

number of helpful: 27 of 28 people (96%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
 Originally posted on November 24, 2007Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts is an expansion pack, but it is sold as a stand alone game, much like the recent Supreme Commander expansion. It provides two new campaigns, covering the Liberation of Caen as the British, and Operation Market Garden as the Panzer Elite. the inclusion of the Panzer Elite is an interesting touch, as few games to date have German campaigns. The campaigns have solid stories, and good replay values through different difficulty levels and medals. However, the game is not really about the campaigns; It is about the new factions, the Brits and the PE. They drastically change the balance of multiplayer, and needless to say, there are still some significant balance issues to work out. All in all though, the new factions are great.British-The British are all about defense. They have the capability to build some amazing defensive emplacements very early on, so watch out for that. Their infantry is very solid, but their armor is weak and expensive.The Panzer Elite- The PE, contrary to their name, are not about panzers, but rather are about fast attacks with mechanized and motorized units. They have a wide variety of halftracks and armored cars, including mortar halftracks and AT halftracks. Perhaps their greatest weapon is their tank destroyer, the Marder II, which is one of the best in the game. On an overall level, Opposing Fronts delivers, but if you are new to the franchise, try the original first.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Opposing Fronts introduces two new single player campaigns. The campaigns feature gameplay from the British perspective and the German perspective. The British campaign features nine missions focusing on the attack by British and Canadian forces on the city of Caen. The German Panzer Elite's campaign features eight playable missions following a Panzer Elite Kampfgruppe in occupied Netherlands that is bracing itself for one of the largest airborne invasions in history.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												By far the best RTS. Relic have nailed the idea of making the whole genre more actiony. They did it with Warhammer but that stuck more to a particular audience and the slight cartoonish graphics put many off. Now in company of heroes it has polished graphics and a subject to suit a wider audience. WW2 although seems quite an over used subject for gaming, has never been as explored as this in an RTS form. The reason for giving it an 8 is because the new expansion was a marketing scheme all along. If you want to survive in multiplayer you must get this game otherwise your whermacht will be screwed by British artillery that can fire at your base from the other end of the map. Be sure to buy and play!

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
NOTE 1:My game time should be around 500 hours by now if I count my time outside of Steam when I first bought this game in 2006.NOTE 2:Also see my Company of Heroes Review here:http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/4560Also see my Company of Heroes: Tales of Valor here:http://steamcommunity.com/id/miyumiayase/recommended/20540TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by THQ (RIP). This game serves as the first official expansion pack to the series which adds two new factions, new units, a German (Panzer Elite) and British campaigns along with new multiplayer maps.The expansion pack 'Opposing Fronts' added 2 new campaigns for the new factions of Great Britain who's plot revolves around the British Royal Army's operation to retake and secure the city of Caen in northern France. On the other-hand, the new Axis campaign featured the Panzer Elite faction in their mission to foil an Allied Operation called 'Market Garden'.PROS:+ Improved special effects+ New Factions+ German and British Campaigns+ New Units are fun to play with+ Standalone Expansion but...(See CON #3)+ Allows players with the expansion to play with players without the expansions and vice versaCONS:- Balance issues- AI is somehow worse than the original- Does not include the original armies unless you have the original game- Campaign has some dull moments- Inconsistent sound / voice levels for some of the unitsCONCLUSION:GOOD EXPANSION but could have used a little more polish. Opposing Fronts is a great expansion that adds a lot of replayability to the original game by adding new factions; new units; new Campaign and a ton of improvements that increases the authentic feel and immersion of the game.MUST BUY for RTS and World War 2 fans whether at full price or on sale. Although, I highly advice the 'Complete Pack' (which includes the original game and the 2 expansions) to have the full experience.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

You can use this Add-on as a seperate game and just use this content or you own the base game and the content adds up - you suddenly have 4 armies, a lot of campaigns and extra units. content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
This review is mostly geared towards people that have a hard time enjoying RTS because of their skill level.Here's just how garbage I am at RTS games, so look at these cons, and then apply them to how good this game must be to outweigh my incompetence.  What I can't do:• Use hotkeys (I use like, 'R' for retreat, and other hotkeys for things you'll use a lot)• Keep track of more than one unit at a time• Plan ahead• Micromanage• Multitask• Not suckWhat I can do:• Click• Pause the game and queue orders (shhhhh)• Dump ridiculous amounts of hours into a game, I should have a bad time with.• Set teammates to hard, and enemies to easy• Artillery barage both teammates and enemies alike• Feel the need to actually write a review about itBut in all seriousness...I've always wished I was good enough to take full command of a battlefield with only hotkeys, and be able to play with my friends in Starcraft, but I had to accept that I'm just not good at the genre.The features of the game, as well as my friend convinced me to buy it, and once I did I couldn't stop playing it, simply because of how much much the gameplay was able to outweigh the mechanics and skill.Oh, and another thing that you could use to reference just how good this game is:Look at my steam libraryLook at how many games I haveLook how many games I thought I'd likeLook at how many "hours" I have on my gamesLook at how much money I've wastedRealize that this game must be something special.P.S.For the hardcore, elite RTS veterans:My review might make it seem like the game is dumbed down, but the point I was trying to get across is that it can be fun for every type of gamer. The game mechanics are super in-depth, and combat is super fast paced. You don't need top worry about the game being too easy.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												(EDIT) First things first. What I've of played of this game is incredible. You care about your troops even though you can make new ones just like Dawn of war. There's plenty of additional defense strucutures to build like Barbed Wire, Tank Traps, Mines, Sand bags and turrets, all of these reuslt in the perfect defense if placed correctly. You can choose whether to play as Axis or Allies, in my opinion the Axis are more fun to play as but for the Allies it's cool to drop troops from Air control onto the battlefieild using battlefield perks - They are basically specific types of troop reinforcement to use such as: Plane and air control, Artillery, etc I recently came across a problem whilst playing the game, It was entirely not the games fault, I'll leave it in the bottom of my review so that it explains the comments.I am new to coh. So I downloaded the Demo a few weeks ago and being a fan of Dawn Of War and WW2 immediately loved what I saw. So I decided to purchase the full game in eager anticipation.I had purchased the New Steam Version and Southern* Fronts DLC. After installing I launched it and couldn't play half the game because It said "You require the original Company Of Heroes gme to play this." Even though I had JUST downloaded it. I went ahead and waited for the DLC to install and loaded that up. Exactly the same problem. I then got annoyed and wanted to play the damn game, so I set up a Skirmish match. the building models and soldier models were gone, only their shadows remained. I looked up a soultion for the problem and someone mentioned changing the grapchical options so I did... It caused the game to go to a black screen and immediately crash. Not happy at all.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The Revolutionary RTS.Gone is the simple spam and zerg tactics of the classic style, gone is the throwaway hordes of troops.Now each man, each vehicle, and where you place them mattered. The environment providing cover, concealment, and chokepoints. Less emphasis on refining your build queue and your most efficient productions. More emphasis on tactical placement, securing vital territory, and improvising on the fly.The Gold Standard every RTS should aspire to.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2011
												One of the best real time strategy games ever made on the PC.  It has a complete destructable environment and unit cover system and suppression system.  Flanking the enemy really means something in this game.  I have played countless hours playing this series I definitely got my monies worth with the first game and the two stand alone expansions paying full retail price.  Getting this series for $9.99 on steam sale is a steal!  Also having this series on steam means it will auto patch to the proper version.   This series have been patched and balanced mutiple times and having to patch manualy is a pain.  Having this on steam is a very big bonus.The Company of Heroes and Opposing Fronts has a long single player campain.  Also Opposing Fronts adds the British and German Panzer Elite forces.Tales of Valor only has a very short campain.  But, focus heavily on mutiplayer with a few additional units for each force and different mutiplayer modes like  1vs1, 2vs2, 3vs3, 4vs4. and more!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2012
												Opposing Fronts is a standard expansion. A very standard expansion. It does everything that an expansion is supposed to do, faction, units, maps, campaign. Adding new things within the same frame as the main game. The problem however is that none of it is particularly inspired.Two new factions are introduced, a defensive British army and a mobile German one. However neither of them really brings anything new to the formula.The campaigns are an utterly standard experience and although the cut-scenes and storyline have been heavily improved upon the gameplay is inferior to that of the original American campaign.Opposing Fronts does what is needed, it gives the single-player fanatics a reason to take Company of Heroes back off the shelf. But it does not give them any reason to keep it down. It is a game that you play and then forget about a few days later.

Posted: June 29, 2012
												Company of Heroes: Opposing Fronts (CoH: OF) is an expansion of the ground-breaking real-time strategy (RTS) game, Company of Heroes. The game, of course, continues to use the same mechanics as the original with an added weather effect and offers two new campaigns for the British and German Panzer Elite (Kampfgruppe Lehr). CoH: OF is worthwhile and it should be a no-brainer for CoH fans, but whether or not you own CoH: OF - you still have interplayability with other players from the original.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												"Company of Heroes" to jedna z najlepszych gier strategicznych o tematyce II WŚ. Jej zaletami są:+świetna i prawie że realistyczna grafika+rozbudowany system zniszczeń i uszkodzeń+rozwinięty system ulepszania armii+możliwość budowania fortyfikacji+przeszkody dające osłonę piechocie+zróżnicowanie oddziałów+unikalne umiejętności specialne poszczególnych jednostek+możliwość wzywania wsparcia i rozbudowy armii+kilka poziomów trudności+długa i wciągająca kampaniaJedyną wadą gry jest to, że zawiera tylko jedną kampanię. Problem można zneutralizować nabywając dodatki "Tales of Valor" oraz "Opposing Fronts" dodające aż 5 kampanii.ZDECYDOWANIE POLECAM TĄ GRĘ KAŻDEMU!!!ENGLISH VERSION:"Company of Heroes" is one of the best strategy games of World War II. Its advantages are:+ Great and almost realistic graphics+ Extensive system of destruction and damage+ System developed to improve the army+ Possibility of building fortifications+ Obstacles giving cover to infantry+ Diversity branches+ Unique skills special guide individuals+ The ability to summon support and expansion of the army+ Several difficulty levels+ Long and captivating campaignThe only drawback to the game is that it contains only one campaign. The problem can be neutralized by purchasing add-ons "Tales of Valor" and "Opposing Fronts" adding up to 5 campaign.STRONGLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME EVERYONE !!!

content:
Posted: May 31, 2011
												Let's play the Imagination Game. You're Relic, and you've just made Company of Heroes, what many consider to be one of the best RTS games in a long while, perhaps of all time. After a series of patches where you've basically changed numbers at random while sobbing into your keyboard and wondering how Blizzard does things, you've finally managed to achieve a semblance of balance in the multiplayer metagame. WHAT DO YOU DO?!If you answered "introduce two ridiculously broken factions that, even if you iron out the multitude of bugs infesting both of them, are going to be very difficult to balance even for people who know what they're doing, which you clearly do not," then you win the Imagination Game because that's what Relic did.Thankfully, though, one of the unbalanced factions is the British, so you get to listen to British accents, including their ridiculous pronunciation of "Lieutenant." Do you see an "F" in there? No? Exactly.
